results:
Based on the search results, I can provide you with information about the verification of the 1889 Polish translation of "Czerwone i czarne" (The Red and the Black) by Stendhal, and its relationship to Tadeusz Boy-Żeleński's translation:

## 1889 Polish Translation Verification

Czerwone i czarne było przekładane na język polski w r. 1889 piórem kobiecym - The Red and the Black was translated into Polish in 1889 by a female translator.

na innym miejscu miałem sposobność wyrazić sąd o tym przekładzie i poprzeć go cytatami oraz ogólniejszymi refleksjami na ten temat - Boy-Żeleński mentioned that he had an opportunity elsewhere to express his opinion about this translation and support it with citations and more general reflections on the topic.

## Boy-Żeleński's Translation

The search results confirm that Tadeusz (Boy) Żeleński was indeed a renowned translator who created what became the canonical Polish translation of "Czerwone i czarne." Czytając Czerwone i czarne oraz Pustelnię parmeńską Stendhala, czytaliśmy właśnie w translacjach Boya - readers experienced Stendhal's works through Boy's translations.

Największym jego dziełem, jak to się mówi – dziełem epokowym jest bez wątpienia licząca ponad sto tomów Biblioteka Boya, czyli zbiór arcydzieł literatury francuskiej w jego kongenialnych przekładach - His greatest work was undoubtedly the Library of Boy collection, containing over one hundred volumes of French literary masterpieces in his congenial translations.

The verification confirms that there was indeed an 1889 Polish translation of Stendhal's "The Red and the Black" by a female translator, which Boy-Żeleński was aware of and had critiqued. However, it was Boy-Żeleński's later translation that became the definitive and widely-read Polish version of the novel.
